content:
Complete rubbish is the best I can say about that. Mostly stories promoted by folk that sell Microsoft products and do not like the Open Source concept for their business profits I would think. No money to be made selling Thunderbird as it's use is free and unrestricted.

A decade ago Mozilla dumped Thunderbird and a new company was formed to run the development of Thunderbird funded by donations from Thunderbird users. Whilst ever folk keep giving the program will continue in development last year an Android version was developed on the bones of the K9 mail app. I understand the intention is for an iPhone version next year, so I would say Thunderbird is growing year on year, not facing extinction.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You will not find a program that picks up from where windows mail left off. period

Fundamentally POP mail is meant to be deleted from the server on download, but over the past decade or so everyone has become a pack rat with regard to their email. Storing it like it was some sort of national archive. The way POP manages to start again each session is because it stores the last email received information somewhere on the local machine. Thunderbird stores this information in a popstate.dat file in the profile folder, one file for each account. In the case of some pop accounts this file can be huge, with a reference to every email on the server. I have no idea where windows mail stored this information, probably in the registry. I will certainly not be looking, as each program maintains it's own "where am I up to" information and it is not transferable from application to application. Even if you were to import all the mails from windows mail, the status would not come over and everything on the server would still be downloaded again.

So all your mail will have to be downloaded again from the server (unless you provider is like Google and offers some web setting to limit downloads or yahoo who limit downloads per account to 10,000). There is nothing in the POP protocol to tell the server you only want mail after a certain date. So there is nothing in the protocol that allows any mail client to do what you are asking. You are essentially asking for the last 20 gallons of water that fell into your rainwater tank. The systems used have no way to identify which 20 gallons is the last 20 gallons. This is not just a Thunderbird limitation it is a POP IMAP and I think exchange limitation. As those three protocols probably account for 99% of non webmail email activity I think you need to stop looking for solutions that really do not exist in the mail client sphere and accept the reality of how email works. If you have changed over yeas ago when Microsoft told you that the program was being retired you would have had years less mail to be downloaded over again.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
winmail.dat is really something Outlook users should only use if they are communicating with other known Outlook users. Often used when on a business intranet network. But for general use they should have disabled it/switched it off. I usually just educate the user to switch it off. The internet is littered with good advice on this. This is a useful link to send to those users/senders. Often they just do not know they are sending it. https://www.thewindowsclub.com/stop-sending-or-receiving-winmail-dat-attachments-outlook


Lookout addon extension info: LookOut (fix version) 6.7 Works with Thunderbird 115.0 - 140.* https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/lookout-fix-version/

At the above link - If you click on the 'view other versions' text link, there is also this version: You can get it at this link: https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/lookout-fix-version/versions/

Version 7.0 Released July 28, 2025 Works with Thunderbird 140.0 - 141.* This version has a strict min version of TB 140.0

Looks like they are working on more updates to stay compatible . So I'm not sure what version you are currently using, but it would help to know or whether you tried the version 7 or not ?!

re :I don't know what an ESR branch is. ESR stands for 'Extended Support Release' You can choose that option when getting a download from :

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Where it says 'Release Channel' you select 'Thunderbird Extended Support Release' from the drop down options. As of 3rd Oct 2025 current download version for this is 140.3.1esr

Process:

  1. Exit Thunderbird.
  2. Uninstall Thunderbird.
  3. Access your profile name folder and delete the file called 'compatibility.ini'
  4. Get 'Thunderbird Extended Support Release' download/install from the link above
  5. Start Thunderbird.

Your question asked about installing an earlier version hence that was the information I provided so that the addon Lookout would be compatible.

However, you mention 'I was hoping to install one of those versions so I could import my Outlook 2010 contacts and emails as a one-off. ' You can import from Outlook using the 140.3.0esr version or 143*

Import them into 'Local Folders' mail account.

In Thunderbird Via 'Menu Bar' toolbar Import > 'Import from outlook' > click on 'Continue' and follow instructions.

Via 'Menu app icon' Tools > Import > 'Import from outlook' > click on 'Continue' and follow instructions.

tpgettys said
I did try that, but Thunderbird reports "No profile found". I don't what that means, but assume it is because Outlook is installed on a different computer.

Thunderbird imports from Outlook. It must be installed and functioning on the computer you wish to do the import on. So install Thunderbird in whatever computer has Outlook and migrate the Thunderbird profile to the new computer.

content:
Disable account hub in Settings/General, then add the account from ⩸ - New Account - Email, with these settings:

imap.mail.yahoo.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

smtp.mail.yahoo.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

Accept cookies in TB (not browser) Settings, and enter the account (not app) password in the OAuth window when asked to allow TB access.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thanks sfhowes. Here’s the solution that worked for me:

Since version 140, TB uses a new Account Hub to create new accounts. This automatic account creation option is enabled by default. It works fine in most cases, but if your account cannot be created, the program freezes (endless spinning wheel).

Go to Settings and uncheck Create accounts from the new Account Hub.

All is good now ;)

content: Google assigns a unique password to each third party client, so the password that works online will not work on a PC with an email ciient, such as thunderbird. Instead, gmail prompts for your online password and then applies an 'app' password to your thunderbird account. My suggestion is to go to settings>privacy&security, click to show passwords and then delete the rows associated with the Gmail account. Be sure also that you have thunderbird set to allow cookies (also at privacy&security). Then, when Gmail prompts for password, enter your online password. Also, user id should be your full gmail address.
creator: davidsk

content:
What is 'Firebird' ? Are you talking about the 'Thunderbird' email client?

Exactly what is the question? You say 'Drafts is empty' which is a statement. No doubt you expected it to contain something. But that would depends upon several things.

You say 'After closing FireBird my draft was deleted', but was it saved in the first place?

You say you cannot offer more information, but you would need to supply a lot more information because believe it or not, we have no knowledge about your computer, type of account or set up etc.

At this point it is vital that you do not compact anything. Please provide the following Information so we can check all is set up correctly. I've also made some suggestions for checks and even a potential rescue.

What OS are you using ? What version of Thunderbird are you using ?

Did you get the download from the official website : https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ OR did you get a download/installation from Windows App Store or Snap or Flatpak or maybe portableapps ? That info is important because it also tells us where to expect the default location of your profile folders.

Are you talking about a POP or an IMAP mail account ? It's important to know because Imap synchs with server to show whatever is on server. That also means we would need to know what are your current settings for what to do with Drafts.

In 'Account Settings' > 'Copies & Folders' for the mail account What have you got selected for 'Drafts' ? Thunderbird would need to know what it's supposed to do with your draft emails. Upload an image showing what settings you are using.

In 'Settings' > 'Composition' Have you selected the checkbox to 'Auto save every X minutes' ? if yes how many minutes is set up ?

When you close a Write new message window you would get prompted to 'Save', 'Discard Changes' or 'Cancel'. Did you specifically click on 'Save' to save the 'Draft' email before closing the Write window? If no then it was not saved.

Is it possible you exited Thunderbird and forgot to save the email as a draft before exiting?

Did you by any chance accidentally or unknowlingly send the email? In which case it may be in the 'Sent' folder or if you used 'Send Later' it would be in the 'Outbox'. I have come across some people who have inadvertantly pressed the Enter/Return key and not realised they had also depressed the Ctrl key - those two keys together are the keyboard means of sending.

Have you checked to see if a filter is operating on the 'Drafts' folder ? Select 'Drafts' folder check the following: The 'Quick Filter' - are any of those icons enabled - they would show a blue bar. For example, if the 'pin' icon was selected then it may be applying a previous filter. If 'Show only unread mail' is selected it will show an empty view if there are no unread emails. So make sure none of those icons are selected.

Using 'Menu Bar' - View > Threads > select 'All (this is the default) - but is it selected? But it's also worth checking to see if you have inadvertantly set up email as ignored - very easy to do - the 'K' key on keyboard will set an email as ignored. You can check this by : View > Threads > also select 'Ignored threads' - if email displays a red circle icon in the threads column header then it was set up as ignored.

Did you check to see if the folder needed to be repaired ?

  • Right click on Drafts folder and select 'Properties'
  • click on 'Repair folder' button
  • click on 'OK'

This action checks the contents of the mbox file that stores emails, and rebuilds the index file to match it.

Have you access that mail account email address via any other method which uses Imap connection such as phone, tablet, laptop or work computer or even directly via webmail using a browser? If you did and you deleted, moved, sent etc ect anything then it would update server and thus update the Thunderbird imap account.

Find out what is currently displayed in the 'Drafts' mbox file and see if you can recover an email which has been 'marked as deleted' and 'hidden'. Assuming you are using a Windows OS and assuming you got Thunderbird download /installtion from the official website:

  • Exit Thunderbird if it's running - this is important
  • In windows search type: %Appdata%
  • Select the %Appdata% file folder option
  • Select the 'Roaming' folder to see contents
  • Select the 'Thunderbird' folder to see contents
  • Select the 'Profiles' folder to see contents
  • Select the 'profile name - various digits' folder to see contents
  • IF POP account - Select the 'Mail' folder to see contents
  • IF IMAP account - Select the 'ImapMail' folder to see contents

Look for a file called 'Drafts' - no extention (not Drafts.msf) Open the 'Drafts' file using a simple text editor eg: ' Notepad'

The oldest emails are at the top. Each email starts with the following lines - this is an example:

  • From - Mon Aug 04 14:40:13 2025
  • X-Mozilla-Status: 0001
  • X-Mozilla-Status2: 00000000

If you see some email content - look for 'X-Mozilla-Status:' does it have this number 0001 ? If no, then please edit that number to say 0001

Work down through file and for each email you want to rescue Edit each X-Mozilla-Status: to say 0001 When finished, Save the file Then delete the index file of same name called 'Drafts.msf'

Finally start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thank you...I am getting some courage now..... How can I roll back to version TB142?
creator: ath.papavasileiou

content:
Αθανάσιος Παπαβασιλείου said
Thank you...I am getting some courage now..... How can I roll back to version TB142?

Open your TB profile:

- go to TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

Then:

- close TB

- install v142 from the appropriate folder at https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/142.0/.

- delete the compatibilty.ini file in the profile folder

- restart TB
creator: siffemoz

content:
%That is generally caused by a failing antivirus program on a POP mail account.

You can try logging into the mail providers webmail and clearing out the spam folder as the antivirus programs appear to be very brittle and when they encounter a malformed email they crash and take the connection with them, hence it keeps restarting at the neginning. As most malformed emails are also spam email it can solve the issue by deleting anything in the spam folder, but it is not always the case. Otherwise pause any scanning of email until you download your mail, including whatever is crashing the antivirus. Then you can enable it again. It is interesting to not that Microsoft does not have a mail scanner in the Defender product. So I respond to lots of these topics and have no mail scanner to fail on my system.

content:
Try this:

Close TB and open the Profile manager. Select the profile you want to use by default > check 'Use the selected profile...' > click 'Start Thunderbird'. 

Also make sure TB menu > Settings > General > System Integration > 'Always check to see...' is enabled and click the 'Check Now' button.

content:
Filters for each account are in a file called msgfilterrules.dat If all else is the same, try copying from one profile to the other. These are text-editable so it's easy to view. And, if the 38gb is for IMAP accounts, do this. - exit thunderbird - locate the imap accounts in profile and delete the message folders - thunderbird will repopulate on new pc - now continue with these steps to copy profile

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
Why, oh why, do folk make life hard for themselves. Have you already read the information that yahoo do make available? https://help.yahoo.com/kb/download-email-yahoo-mail-third-party-sln28681.html 

It is lacking in detail sadly and of a generally poor quality.  But then so is just about everything about the service.  Anecdotally it appears that mail from the server name mentioned only downloads and synchronization does not occur. This is reinforced by the last line on the page about two way syncing.   I really do not know though and yahoo appears incapable of issuing anything resembling complete information.

IMAP is as you have demonstrated to yourself is syncronised to the server. Exactly what the service Yahoo offers does I do not know but as far as I can see it makes the mail sync server to client but not the other way. One things to be sure, unless you manually set the server names for the incoming server your account is currently not configured to use it so I suggest you change the server name and again wait for things to stabilize.

Now the next part is to one concerning me. Are you trying to make something you can access or are you only concerned to make sure you "have a copy" The fomats for the export you use will very much depend on your usage going forward.

However the tools you will use are the same. This addon https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

The import export tools addon offers many export formats, but perhaps the best for most archival work is the venerable MBOX format. That places each email in a folder in a single very large file. The downside being you have to import the folder to Thunderbird or another mail client that uses MBOX format to read the email.

You could export to hundreds of thousands of individual eml files. These can be read by double clicking them in a mail client, but the trouble is identifying which of the thousands and thousands of email you want to double click on.

The final option I will mention is to re-import MBOX files immediately to Thunderbird where you can access the folders in the local Folders account the same as you access them in the yahoo account now. BTW I have no idea how you delete thundreds of thousands of email from yahoo if the sync is one way/
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thank you Matt for responding. I am so unsavvy about programs, emails, internet, etc. I did reach out to expert help from Yahoo, and they told me to use Thunderbird. The expert said he didn't know what else to do, and that he could not help with Thunderbird. I also asked the Tech Geeks at Geek Squad, and they said the same. They suggested that I go through the thousands of emails and save and/or download any attachments separately. This would require literally hundreds of hours to accomplish. To answer your next comment about how I want to use the saved emails/attachments is this: I need to free up my Yahoo account because they are now charging me for it. I need to access past emails/attachments if I need to look up data for clients or for myself personally. So yes, I need to be able to access the info on them and thought I could do it by using Thunderbird. Any thoughts? Please be very simplistic in your answer and patient with me. I don't even know what IMAP is, why my yahoo is synchronizing with Thunderbird, etc. Many thanks.
creator: realtormaryanderson

content:
I think the very first question here must be. Are the emails appearing in the inbox on the mail server?

POP only accesses what the RFC refers to as the mail drop. In practice most web mail services interpret this to be the inbox as that is where all incoming mail goes.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thanks for your quick response.

Yes, the emails were showing up in the Inbox of my ISP's mail server.

Having exhausted all options to get Thunderbird to download the messages, I had to go through them and manually delete the spam which comprised the vast majority of the messages. Then, for the small number of remaining messages, I forwarded each one to myself. When these new forwarded messages appeared in the Inbox (right alongside the original messages), Thunderbird downloaded them, and deleted them from the Inbox. My final step was to delete the original messages, leaving my Inbox empty as it normally is (once Thunderbird has downloaded newly arrived messages).

So, some time wasted, but the problem is resolved and hopefully won't recur, though I may have to periodically look at the mail server to be sure everything's getting downloaded properly.

Best regards...
creator: amb.biz.1
